case_name: State of Maharashtra v. Prabbakar Pandurang Sanzgiri

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 107 of 1965 filed by State of Maharashtra.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 107 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order, dated June 22, 1965 of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Applica- tion No. 613 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated June 22, 1965 of Bombay High Court in Criminal Application No. 613 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 107 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order, dated June 22, 1965 of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Applica- tion No. 613 of 1965. Niren De, Additional Solicitor-General and B. R. G. K. Achar, for the appellant.

facts.text: Prabbakar Pandurang Sanzgiri detained by Government of Maharashtra under S. 30(1)(b) of Defence of India Rules, 1962 in Bombay District Prison to prevent prejudicial acts.

anchor.surface_text: Prabbakar Pandurang Sanzgiri, who has been detained by the Government of Maharashtra under S. 30 1  b  of the Defence of India Rules, 1962, in the Bombay District Prison in order to prevent him from acting in a manner pre- judicial to the defence of India, public safety and maintenance of public order,

facts.text: Detenu wrote book in Marathi titled Anucha Antarangaat Inside the Atom with permission of Government.

anchor.surface_text: has written, with the permission of the said Government, a book in Marathi under the title Anucha Antarangaat  Inside the Atom . The learned Judges of the High Court, who had gone through the table of companytents of the book.

facts.text: Bombay High Court Judges opined that the book deals with theory of elementary particles objectively, educational on quantum theory, purely scientific, no prejudice to defence etc.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court, who had gone through the table of companytents of the book. expressed their opinion on the book thus we are satisfied that the manuscript book deals with the theory of elementary particles in -in objective way. The manuscript does number purport to be a research work but it purports to be a book written with a view to educate the people and disseminate knowledge regarding quantum theory.

facts.text: In September 1964, detenu applied to Government of Maharashtra for permission to send manuscript out of jail for publication.

anchor.surface_text: In September, 1964, the detenu applied to the Government of Maharashtra seeking permission to send the manuscript out of the jail for publication but the Government by its letter, dated March 27, 1965, rejected the request.

facts.text: Government of Maharashtra rejected request by letter dated March 27, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: but the Government by its letter, dated March 27, 1965, rejected the request. He again applied to the Superintendent, Arthur Road Prison, for permission to send the manuscript out and that too was rejected.

facts.text: Detenu applied to Superintendent, Arthur Road Prison for permission to send manuscript, rejected.

anchor.surface_text: He again applied to the Superintendent, Arthur Road Prison, for permission to send the manuscript out and that too was rejected. Thereafter, he filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Maharashtra at Bombay

facts.text: Detenu filed petition under Art. 226 in Bombay High Court for direction to permit sending manuscript to wife for publication.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, he filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Maharashtra at Bombay for directing the State of Maharashtra to permit him to send out the manuscript of the book written by him for its eventual publication.

facts.text: Government in counter-affidavit did not allege publication prejudicial but said not required to permit publication while detained.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Maharashtra in the companynter-affidavit did number allege that the publication of the said book would be prejudicial to the objects of the Defence of India Act, but averred that the Government was number required by law to permit the detenu to publish books while in detention.

facts.text: Bombay High Court held no curb on civil rights by detention, no rules prohibiting sending book for publication, directed Government to allow sending to wife.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Bombay held that the civil rights and liberties of a citizen were in numberway curbed by the order of detention and that it was always open to the detenu to carry on his activities within the companyditions governing his detention. It further held that there were numberrules prohibiting a detenu from sending a book outside the jail with a view to get it published. In that view the High Court directed the Government to allow the manuscript book to be sent by the detenu to his wife for its eventual publication.

facts.text: State of Maharashtra preferred appeal to Supreme Court against High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Maharashtra has preferred the present appeal against the said order of the High Court.

facts.text: Bombay Conditions of Detention Order, 1951 regulates terms of first respondent's detention.

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay Conditions of Detention Order, 1951. which regulates the terms of the first respondents detention, does number companyfer on him any privilege or right to write a book and send it out of the prison for publication.

facts.text: No condition in Bombay Conditions of Detention Order, 1951 regarding writing or sending books for publication.

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay Conditions of Detention Order, 1951, does number companytain any companydition as regards the writing of books by a detenu or sending them out of jail for publication.

facts.text: Sub-rule (iii) of r.17 of Bombay Conditions of Detention Order, 1951 provides for censoring letters of security prisoners.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-rule  iii  of r. 17 of the said Order reads All letters to and from security prisoners shall be censored by the Commissioner or the Superintendent, a the case may be. If in the opinion of the Commissioner or the Superintendent, the dispatch or delivery of any letter is likely to be detrimental to the public interest or safety or the discipline of the place of detention,

facts.text: Maharashtra Government did not rely on sub-rule (iii) r.17 in counter-affidavit or before High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Maharashtra Government has number relied upon this rule. In deed, in the companynter-affidavit its case was number that it prohibited the sending of the book for publication under the said sub-rule, but that it was number required by law to permit the detenu to publish books while in detention

facts.text: Supreme Court holds no restriction in detention conditions on sending book for publication, so refusal illegal.

anchor.surface_text: As there is numbercondition in the Bombay Conditions of Detention Order, 1951, prohibiting a detenu from writing a book or sending it for publication, the State of Maharashtra infringed the personal liberty of the first respondent in derogation of the law whereunder he is detained.

facts.text: Detention under sub-r.4 r.30 Defence of India Rules, conditions determined by Government of Maharashtra as per Bombay Conditions of Detention Order, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the power company- ferred under sub-r.  4  of r. 30 of the Rules, the Government of. Maharashtra determined that the companyditions as to maintenance, discipline and the punishment of offenses and breaches of discipline governing persons ordered to be detained in any place in the State of Maharashtra, shall be the same as those companytained in the Bombay Conditions of Detention Order, 1951.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Subba Rao J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Subba Rao J. Prabbakar Pandurang Sanzgiri, who has been detained by the Government of Maharashtra under S. 30 1  b  of the Defence of India Rules, 1962,

facts.text: Detenu is first respondent, State of Maharashtra is appellant.

concepts.interpretation: If a person was deprived of his personal liberty not under the Act or a rule or order made thereunder but in contravention thereof, his right to move the said Courts in that regard would not be suspended. The question, therefore. in this case is whether the first respondents liberty has been restricted in terms of the Defence of India Rules whereunder he was detained. If it was in contravention of the said Rules, he would have the right to approach the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

holdings.text: No restrictions other than those prescribed under sub-r. 4 of r. 30 of the Defence of India Rules can be imposed on a detenu.

anchor.surface_text: Briefly stated, the scheme of the said C. and I./65-2 provisions is that a person can be detained if the appropriate Government is satisfied that in order to prevent him from doing the prejudicial acts mentioned in r. 30 of the Rules it is necessary to detain him in prison subject to the conditions imposed in the manner prescribed in sub-r.  4  of r. 30 of the Rules. To put it in a negative form, no restrictions other than those prescribed under sub-r.  4  of r. 30 can be imposed on a detenu.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of Defence of India Rules limits restrictions to those in conditions order under sub-r.4 r.30; extra restrictions derogate from law of detention.

holdings.text: The Bombay Conditions of Detention Order, 1951, does not contain any condition as regards the writing of books by a detenu or sending them out of jail for publication. There is, therefore, no restriction on the detenu in respect of that activity.

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay Conditions of Detention Order, 1951, does not contain any condition as regards the writing of books by a detenu or sending them out of jail for publication. There is no provision in that Order dealing with the writing or publication of books by a detenu. There is, therefore, no restriction on the detenu in respect of that activity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual reading of the Order reveals absence of any relevant prohibiting condition.

holdings.text: Sub-rule (iii) of r.17 prima facie applies only to letters to and from security prisoners and does not regulate the sending out of prison books for publication.

anchor.surface_text: Prima facie the said sub-rule applies only to letters to and from security prisoners and does not regulate the sending out of prison books for publication.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual distinction between letters and books; government did not rely on it.

holdings.text: The conditions in the Bombay Conditions of Detention Order regulating restrictions on personal liberty of detenu are not privileges conferred but conditions subject to which liberty can be restricted.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the said conditions regulating the restrictions on the personal liberty of a detenu are not privileges conferred on him, but are the conditions subject to which his liberty can be restricted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive construction rejects narrow 'privilege' view; otherwise absurd results like no food; conditions define permissible restrictions.

holdings.text: As there is no condition prohibiting a detenu from writing a book or sending it for publication, the State infringed the personal liberty of the first respondent in derogation of the law whereunder he is detained.

anchor.surface_text: As there is no condition in the Bombay Conditions of Detention Order, 1951, prohibiting a detenu from writing a book or sending it for publication, the State of Maharashtra infringed the personal liberty of the first respondent in derogation of the law whereunder he is detained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of condition + scheme of rules = extra restriction contravenes detention law, even under Arts.358/359.

holdings.text: The appellant acted contrary to law in refusing to send the manuscript book of the detenu out of the jail to his wife for eventual publication.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, therefore, acted contrary to law in refusing to send the manuscript book of the detenu out of the jail to his wife for eventual publication.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of above to facts: refusal without legal basis illegal.

holdings.text: If deprived of liberty not under the Act/rule but in contravention thereof, right to move High Court/Supreme Court under Art.226/32 not suspended.

anchor.surface_text: If a person was deprived of his personal liberty not under the Act or a rule or order made thereunder but in contravention thereof, his right to move the said Courts in that regard would not be suspended. The question, therefore, in this case is whether the first respondents liberty has been restricted in terms of the Defence of India Rules whereunder he was detained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conditional nature of President's Art.359 order; textual reading.

precedents.case_name: A. K. Gopalan v. State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: if a citizen loses the freedom of his person by reason of a lawful detention, he cannot claim the rights under Art. 19 of the Constitution as the rights enshrined in the said article are only the attributes of a free man

precedents.citation: A. K. Gopalans case 1 , at p. 29 1.

anchor.surface_text: A. K. Gopalans case 1 , at p. 29 1. If a mans person is free, it is then and then only that he can exercise a variety of other auxiliary rights, that is to say, he can, within certain limits, speak what he likes, assemble where he likes, form any associations or unions, move about freely as his own inclination may direct, reside and settle anywhere he likes and practise any profession or carry on any occupation, trade or business.

precedents.case_name: A. K. Gopalan v. State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: If a mans person is free, it is then and then only that he can exercise a variety of other auxiliary rights [...] These are attributes of the freedom of the person and are consequently attached to the person
precedents.cited_holding: If a mans person is free, it is then and then only that he can exercise a variety of other auxiliary rights, that is to say, he can, within certain limits, speak what he likes, assemble where he likes, form any associations or unions, move about freely as his own inclination may direct, reside and settle anywhere he likes and practise any profession or carry on any occupation, trade or business. These are attributes of the freedom of the per-son and are consequently attached to the person.

anchor.surface_text: the second Kochunnis case 2 1960 3 S.C.R. 887. the views of the learned Judges may be broadly summarized under the following heads  1  to invoke Art. 19 1  of the Constitution, a law shall be made directly infringing that right  2  Arts. 21 and 22 constitute a self-contained code and  3  the freedoms in Art. 19 postulate a free man.

precedents.cited_proposition: views of the learned Judges in A. K. Gopalan's case may be broadly summarized under heads: 1 to invoke Art. 19(1), law must directly infringe; 2 Arts. 21 and 22 self-contained code; 3 freedoms in Art. 19 postulate free man

anchor.surface_text: A. K. Gopalans case 1  is not the last word on the subject.

anchor.surface_text: Briefly stated, the scheme of the said C. and I./65-2 provisions is that a person can be detained if the appropriate Government is satisfied that in order to prevent him from doing the prejudicial acts mentioned in r. 30 of the Rules it is necessary to detain him in prison subject to the conditions imposed in the manner prescribed in sub-r.  4  of r. 30 of the Rules. To put it in a negative form, no restrictions other than those prescribed under sub-r.  4  of r. 30 can be imposed on a detenu.

Briefly stated, the scheme of the said C. and I./65-2 provisions is that a person can be detained if the appropriate Government is satisfied that in order to prevent him from doing the prejudicial acts mentioned in r. 30 of the Rules it is necessary to detain him in prison subject to the conditions imposed in the manner prescribed in sub-r.  4  of r. 30 of the Rules. To put it in a negative form, no restrictions other than those prescribed under sub-r.  4  of r. 30 can be imposed on a detenu.

edges.explanation: h2 stating no condition on writing/sending books supports h5 conclusion of infringement due to no prohibiting condition
Holding h2 that Bombay Conditions of Detention Order lacks provision on writing books or sending out for publication addresses issue i3 regarding authority to prevent sending materials

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay Conditions of Detention Order, 1951, does not contain any condition as regards the writing of books by a detenu or sending them out of jail for publication. There is no provision in that Order dealing with the writing or publication of books by a detenu. There is, therefore, no restriction on the detenu in respect of that activity.

The Bombay Conditions of Detention Order, 1951, does not contain any condition as regards the writing of books by a detenu or sending them out of jail for publication. There is no provision in that Order dealing with the writing or publication of books by a detenu. There is, therefore, no restriction on the detenu in respect of that activity.

Holding h4 clarifying that conditions are not privileges but limits on liberty directly addresses issue i4 on privileges conferred by detention order

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the said conditions regulating the restrictions on the personal liberty of a detenu are not privileges conferred on him, but are the conditions subject to which his liberty can be restricted.

We, therefore, hold that the said conditions regulating the restrictions on the personal liberty of a detenu are not privileges conferred on him, but are the conditions subject to which his liberty can be restricted.

anchor.surface_text: As there is no condition in the Bombay Conditions of Detention Order, 1951, prohibiting a detenu from writing a book or sending it for publication, the State of Maharashtra infringed the personal liberty of the first respondent in derogation of the law whereunder he is detained.

As there is no condition in the Bombay Conditions of Detention Order, 1951, prohibiting a detenu from writing a book or sending it for publication, the State of Maharashtra infringed the personal liberty of the first respondent in derogation of the law whereunder he is detained.
The appellant, therefore, acted contrary to law in refusing to send the manuscript book of the detenu out of the jail to his wife for eventual publication.

anchor.surface_text: If a person was deprived of his personal liberty not under the Act or a rule or order made thereunder but in contravention thereof, his right to move the said Courts in that regard would not be suspended. The question, therefore, in this case is whether the first respondents liberty has been restricted in terms of the Defence of India Rules whereunder he was detained.

If a person was deprived of his personal liberty not under the Act or a rule or order made thereunder but in contravention thereof, his right to move the said Courts in that regard would not be suspended. The question, therefore, in this case is whether the first respondents liberty has been restricted in terms of the Defence of India Rules whereunder he was detained.
